title: 115_hr2852
content: The "Election Protection & Integrity Certification Act" or the "EPIC Act" ensures that foreign funds will not be used for any contribution or expenditure in connection with elections in the United States. The EPIC Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to require organizations seeking tax exemption to certify that they will not use foreign funds for contributions or expenditures related to elections. The EPIC Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to require organizations seeking tax exemption to certify that they will not use foreign funds for contributions or expenditures related to elections. Organizations must also include a certification with their notification as described in subsection (g) of the Code. The EPIC Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to require organizations seeking tax exemption to certify that they will not use foreign funds for contributions or expenditures related to elections. This certification prohibits organizations from using foreign funds for contributions, donations, or expenditures in connection with any Federal, State, or local election, political party committees, or electioneering communications. Additionally, organizations are not allowed to solicit, accept, or receive foreign contributions or donations for election-related purposes. The EPIC Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit organizations from using foreign funds for contributions or expenditures related to elections. The Act also prohibits soliciting, accepting, or receiving contributions from foreign nationals. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to conduct a study on the political activities of corporations to determine if foreign money is being used in U.S. elections. The EPIC Act prohibits organizations from using foreign funds for election-related expenses and contributions. It also prohibits accepting contributions from foreign nationals. The Act mandates a study on corporations' political activities to identify foreign money in U.S. elections. The effective date for the amendments is specified for applications and returns. SEC. 3. Including certifications in reports filed under Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 by organizations making disbursements for independent expenditures or electioneering communications. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include certifications for organizations making independent expenditures and electioneering communications. Organizations must certify that they did not use foreign funds for the expenditures. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require organizations described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to certify that they did not use foreign funds for disbursements. These amendments apply to reports filed after the enactment of this Act.
